questionListItems.title: How can my child withdraw/change CCA?

answer.body: A student is strongly encouraged to remain in their CCA from P3 to P6. In the event a change is required, parent to download the CCA Withdrawal/Transfer form from the school website. The parent to then submit the completed form to the CCA Teacher-in-charge for follow up. (CCA Transfers will only be reviewed from Term 4 Week 4 of the current year. Urgent cases will be reviewed on a case by case basis).

questionListItems.title: If my child is in a sport that is not being offered by the school (and taking part in competitions), must he still take part in a CCA?  How can the school support him in his sport?

answer.body: For students pursuing a programme with an External Sports Association or a Club, parent may write in to the HOD CCA to request for the child to be exempted from certain CCA sessions/make alternative arrangement for CCA days. Parent can work with HOD CCA if more support is required.

questionListItems.title: How are students selected for their CCAs after they make their choices?

answer.body:
The school will allocate the CCAs based on rank of choice and availability of slots in that CCA (going down the choices).
For students who do not wish to accept the invite(s) in the invitation letter given (for selected students), the school will allocate the slot to (a) students who accept the invite and (b) students who place that particular CCA as their first choice.

questionListItems.title: How can students have a better sense of the CCAs offered in Ai Tong School?

answer.body: Information on CCAs offered in ATS can be found in the school's website.  An online CCA fair will also be made available to the P2 students closer to the CCA selection window.

CCAs are a key component of studentsâ€™ holistic education.
Through CCAs, students discover their interests and talents. CCAs also provide platforms for students to develop their character, learn values, social emotional competencies and other relevant skills to prepare them for future challenges.
CCAs bring students from diverse backgrounds together. By learning and interacting with one another, students develop friendships and deepen their sense of belonging to the school and community.
Participation in a CCA is strongly encouraged at the primary level.

questionListItems.title: How are students selected for the Bi-cultural Chinese Elective Programme (BiCEP) programme?

answer.body:
Each year, P3 students will be recommended by their Form Teachers and Subject Teachers, based on the following:
1) ability and motivation towards language learning (both EL and CL) demonstrated in class;
2) desire and passion to learn Chinese culture (i.e. the interest level) based on P1-P3 culture modules observation;
3) Conduct of the child;
4) Able to pass the Culture Quiz conducted in Term 4

*Parents who feel that their children satisfy the eligibility criteria may also recommend their children for the interview.

Opt to take HCL in P5 and P6:
Student is required to take HCL in P5 and P6.

Interview
If your child is shortlisted to attend an interview for this programme after meeting the eligibility criteria, you will be given written notification of the interview.
After the interview process, only students selected for this programme will receive a written notification of their selection.
Generally, students diagnosed with some learning disability may apply and be considered for MT exemption by MOE.

questionListItems.title: How are the students banded at P5?

answer.body: All 4 subjects will be taken into consideration at the end of P4. Students are grouped into 3 broad bands with mixed ability in each of the bands.

questionListItems.title: How will the P6 students be ready for Preliminary examinations or the PSLE that are time-bound, given that there are no more mid-year examinations?

answer.body: Time will be allocated for timed-practices in the course of the year to help the students prepare for their Preliminary examinations and the PSLE.

questionListItems.title: With no mid-year exams, how can school and parents know the progress of each student?

answer.body: Apart from termly reviews which are used to monitor students' academic progress, teachers use formative assessments through students' daily work as an ongoing process to elicit evidence of student learning and understanding of what was taught.
